50.author: deannevee
50.body:
FMLA is federally protected time off. It can be paid or unpaid. FMLA can be paired with other benefits, including but not limited to: sick time, vacation time, PTO, and short term or long term disability leave. Not having access to the paid benefits (as in, if your PTO runs out) doesn’t mean that you aren’t still covered by FMLA. That’s why you file for FMLA.

Filing for FMLA is pretty minimal. It was a one sheet, front and back, piece of paper. I put my name, address, SS number on the front, and my doctor put my  requested accommodations on the back and signed it with her NPI. There was a spot for limitations in lieu of accommodations (like “can only lift 10 pounds”). There was no need for a diagnosis of any kind. Just “needs 3 days off per month”. 

In contrast, when I went on disability leave that required constant paperwork.

At my current position, I have an accommodation for a max of 3 covered days off per month. I can choose to use my PTO, or choose to make up the time (as in work extra hours in the same pay period) or choose not to be paid.
